title-group.article-title: Low-salt restructured fish products from Atlantic mackerel (Scomber scombrus) with texture resembling turkey breast

article-meta.aff: Department of Analytical Chemistry, Faculty of Veterinary Science, University of Santiago de Compostela, Lugo, Spain

author-notes.corresp: M Vázquez, Department of Analytical Chemistry, Faculty of Veterinary Science, University of Santiago de Compostela, Lugo 27002, Spain Email: manuel.vazquez@usc.es

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Atlantic mackerel (Scomber scombrus) is a pelagic and migratory species that is usually caught with other fish as bycatch. The aim of this work was to obtain low-salt restructured fish products from Atlantic mackerel resembling turkey breast using transglutaminase (0.2 U/g) as binder. NaCl concentration (0–20 g/kg), temperature (25–40 °C) and time of incubation (30–90 min) were assayed. The texture parameters (Warner–Bratzler force and Warner–Bratzler work) and expressible water were compared to those of turkey breast. Mathematical models were obtained to determine the effect of these variables on the texture of Atlantic mackerel restructured products. Optimal conditions to obtain a similar texture than turkey breast were found. The overall optimization point out that the treatment at 31.8 °C for 63.35 min using a NaCl concentration of 8.45 g/kg allowed to obtain restructured products from Atlantic mackerel with texture and expressible water similar to those of turkey breast. Color parameters (L*, a* and b*) of the product were also similar to those of turkey breast. The results showed the feasibility of producing low-salt restructured products from Atlantic mackerel resembling turkey breast using transglutaminase.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Atlantic mackerel (Scomber scombrus) is a pelagic and migratory fish, which is present in the water of the continental platform. Atlantic mackerel is refused to diet for several reasons. Usually due to its small size, it is caught with other fish as bycatch and one alternative is processing the muscle mechanically. At present, there are equipments and processes to recover the fish proteins making commercial and attractive products for human consume (García-Sifuentes et al., 2009; Larrazábal et al., 2010; Madrid et al., 1999; Velázquez et al., 2007). Pulps of mackerel may be used for restructured products such as a frozen fillet ready for cooking (Uresti et al., 2004).

The biochemistry of fish muscle is distinct from that of mammals and birds. Therefore fish products must be processed in a different way than red meat and poultry. Particular phenomena in fish products are modori and suwari (setting). Modori is a deteriorative phenomenon that takes place at temperatures near 60 °C. It has been associated with the presence and activity of endogenous serine and cysteine muscle proteases (An et al., 1996; Ramírez et al., 2002; Ramos et al., 1999). The systems of fish muscle incubated at temperatures below 40 °C can join due to the activity of an endogenous transglutaminase. This phenomenon is called suwari and it is highly dependent on fish species and habitat temperature (Suzuki, 1986). In cold-water species, suwari occurs at 25 °C in 2 h, while in tropical species it occurs at higher temperature, with optimal level at 38 °C in 1 h (Ramírez et al., 2000 a, b).

Restructuring processes allow to obtain products with high commercial value from different sources: non-commercial fish species, fishes with size smaller than commercial (such as caught as shrimp bycatch), and trimmings from filleting of commercial fish species (Sun, 2009). The most widespread technique consists in solubilize and extract myofibrillar proteins with salt to obtain sticky exudates, which are used to bind protein pieces (Kuraishi et al., 1997). There are many reports in the literature about restructured products by using the addition of proteins such as egg white (Yetim and Ockerman, 1995), casein and beef plasma-thrombin (Baker et al., 2000) collagen, hydrocolloids such as carrageenan or alginate and the enzyme transglutaminase (Moreno et al., 2008; Pacheco-Aguirre et al., 2010; Uresti et al., 2004). With the exception of transglutaminase, all these additives and components involve changes in texture (Larrazábal et al., 2010; Rivera et al., 2010), flavor or color of the restructured product.

Microbial transglutaminase (MTG; EC 2.3.2.13) is produced by Streptoverticillium mobaraense. Microbial transglutaminase has the capacity to modify the properties of restructured products through acyl transfer reactions between the γ-carboxyamide group of peptides bound to glutamine residues (acil donors) and a variety of primary amines (acil acceptors), including the ε-amino group of lysine residues in certain proteins (Hinz et al., 2007). The modification of proteins can occur through cross-linking reactions, deamidation and amine incorporation. Cross-linking seems to be the most dominant reaction and results in the formation of ε-(γ-glutamyl)-lysine intra and intermolecular isopeptide bonds, and in the formation of polymers with higher molecular weights (Hiller and Lorenzen, 2009; Jong and Koppelman, 2002). The cross-linking between proteins through the action of transglutaminase can modify several functional properties of foods, such as solubility, heat stability and the gelation, emulsifying and rheological properties (Hinz et al., 2007).

A viable option to advantage low value species can be to bone and to incubate their mince under 40 °C in presence of microbial transglutaminase to obtain a restructured product like sausage meat. Restructuring techniques with transglutaminase need NaCl (20–30 g/kg) to solubilize the proteins (Ramírez et al., 2007). The level of NaCl employed during massaging is important because it influences the amount of exuded protein obtained, which acts in binding and affect the protein aggregation mechanism (Téllez-Luis et al., 2002). However, consumers are demanding healthier foods and there is a great interest in lightly salted products. To meet this public health demand, the food industry should increase the supply of low-salt foods because reducing salt intake can prevent and control adverse blood pressure levels in humans (Luciano, 2009; Narhimen et al., 1998).

On the other hand, fish consumption has been shown to be related to reduce sudden cardiac death. Recent reports of health reported an inverse relationship between blood levels of fatty long-chain omega-3 and risk of sudden death in men with no history of cardiovascular disease (Carrero et al., 2005; Ergönül et al., 2010; Fernández-Michel et al., 2008; Kris-Etherton et al., 2003; Noriega-Rodriguez et al., 2009).

The food industry is changing rapidly, driven by changes in food technology and demand, among other factors. The sausages are in a category of products that clearly respond to consumer preferences. Today, the sausage is a product consumed by the population as a substitute of meat in many meals. These sausages provide new opportunities to save time and money. Several dietetic questionnaire show that the most preferred meals as the first course were pasta (58.1%) and rice (24.3%); as second course, meat (76.7%) with French fries (32.9%), and for dessert, fruit (34.2%), yoghurt (30.1%) and sweets (23.3%). Vegetables (48.9%), fish (14.1%) and beans (13%) were the least preferred (Durá et al., 2000; Serrano et al., 2006; WHO, 2003). The prevalent alimentary habits in population are characterized by an excessive consumption of meat and sugar together with a deficient consumption of fruit, vegetables, cereals, beans and fish. One option to change this situation is to obtain complementary products to increase consumption of these meals. In this way, it is possible to correct deficiencies in fish-consuming habits by developing a new restructured fish product with the texture of a meat sausage. If at the same time a low-salt product is obtained, the achievement of a health benefit is double.

The aim of this work was to obtain low-salt restructured fish products from Atlantic mackerel (Scomber scombrus) using transglutaminase resembling the texture and expressible water of turkey breast. At the same time, this novel process can give a healthy product and an added-value to this species.

sec.title: Raw materials
sec.p: Fresh gutted Atlantic mackerel was obtained from a local market (Lugo, Spain). Fishes were stored in ice during transport to the laboratory and then thoroughly rinsed with ice-cold tap water. Skin and bones were removed manually. The resulting fish mince was washed with distilled water (ratio muscle:water, 1:4) and temperature <15 °C.

Commercial transglutaminase was obtained from BDF natural ingredients (Girona, Spain). The enzyme activity was determined by the colorimetric procedure proposed by Grossowicz et al. (1950). The enzyme activity was measured and the real value in the enzyme lot used was 37 units/g (U/g).

sec.title: Production of restructured Atlantic mackerel products
sec.p:
Muscle of fish drained was chopped for 30–40 s in a blender. All variables involved in this study, including the ingredients, are shown in Table 1. The ingredients were weighed and added to minced fish and mixing manually for 3 min. Three concentrations of NaCl (0, 10 or 20 g/kg) were assayed whereas the transglutaminase activity was fixed at 0.2 U/g. The mince was packed with sausage form and then immersed in water bath for the incubation stage. Three levels of temperature and time incubation of (25, 32.5, 40 °C and 30, 60, 90 min) were assayed. Immediately afterwards the products were immersed in a water bath at 90 °C for 15 min. Then the restructured products were immediately removed and placed in an ice-water bath to cool at 4–5 °C for 30 min. All restructured products were stored for 12 h at 4 °C in plastic bags before the analysis of mechanical properties. Table 1.
Variables involved in the experimental design for the restructured Atlantic mackerel products and their nomenclature, units and values or ranges
Nomenclature Units Values or ranges

Microbial transglutaminase
U/g 0.2

Stage of mixing

Cooking temperature Tc °C 90
Cooking time tc min 15
Cooling temperature Te °C 4–5
Cooling time te min 30
Time of waiting until analysis ta h 12
Temperature of waiting until analysis Ta °C 4
(b) Independent variables
Incubation temperature T °C (25, 32.5, 40)
Incubation time t min (30,60, 90)
NaCl S g/kg (0, 10, 20)
(c) Independent normalized variables
Temperature of incubation x1
(−1, 0, 1)
Time of incubation x2
(−1, 0, 1)

(d) Dependent variables
Expressible water Ew %
Warner–Bratzler force Fwb N
Warner–Bratzler work Wwb N s

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: The samples of restructured Atlantic mackerel were cut into small cubes (2.5 × 2.5 × 2.5 cm3). The samples were equilibrated at room temperature (Cardoso et al., 2010) for 30 min in plastic bags to avoid dehydration before mechanical properties were measured. Mechanical properties were determined using a TA-XTplus (Stable Micro System, Viena Court, UK).

Warner–Bratzler analysis was performed using an aluminium Warner-Bratzler probe. Samples were compressed to 80% of their initial height using a compression speed of 0.5 mm/s (Campo et al., 2000; Pérez-Won et al., 2006). Warner–Bratzler force and Warner–Bratzler work were recorded for each treatment and six samples were analyzed form each treatment (Uresti et al., 2003).

sec.title: Experimental design and statistical analysis
sec.p: Response surface methodology was used to study the effect and interactions of three independent experimental variables (NaCl concentration, temperature and time of incubation) on textural properties of restructured Atlantic mackerel products. Experimental design was purposed by Box and Benkhen (1960) and statistical analyses were performed using the software Design-Expert 7.1.1. (Stat-Ease Inc., Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA). This design was formed by combining low-level factorial designs with incomplete block designs. This procedure creates designs with desirable statistical properties but, most important, with only a fraction of the experiments required for a three-level factorial design (Delgado et al., 2009).

The factors and ranges studied were: NaCl (S), 0–20 g/kg; T, 25–40 °C and t, 30–90 min on the basis of previous studies. Seventeen experiments combining the three variables were performed following the design in Table 2. Table 2.
Operational conditions assayed with the experimental design
Experiment Independent variables

T t S x1 x2 x3

13 25 90 10 −1 1 0
14 32.5 60 10 0 0 0
15 32.5 60 10 0 0 0

17 25 30 10 −1 −1 0
For computation purposes, the normalized, dimensionless variables x1, x2 and x3 were defined as (1) (2) (3)

The interrelationship between the studied variables and the dependent and independent variables was established through a model that includes linear terms, interaction and second order terms. The mathematical model used as a first approximation can be summarized in the equation (4) (4) Where V is the dependent variable in every case, xi is the independent variable normalized (x1, x2, x3), a0, ai, bi and cij are the coefficients of the regression calculated with the experimental tests by multiple linear regressions. The results were analyzed using analysis of variance (ANOVA). Model terms were selected based on the p-value with 95% confidence level. Partial models of the quadratic model were also obtained and analyzed by ANOVA (Martínez et al., 2011; Rossa et al., 2011).

sec.title: Expressible water
sec.p: The amount of expressible water (Ew) for each treatment was measured. Samples were weighed (2 ± 0.2 g) and put onto two layers of filter paper. Then placed at the bottom of 50 ml centrifuge tubes and centrifuged at 1000 g for 15 min at 4 °C. Immediately after centrifugation the wet filter papers were removed and the fish samples were reweighed. The percentage of expressible water was calculated as (5) (5) Where Ew is the percentage of expressible water, G0 is the initial weight and G is the final weight. Four samples were analyzed for each treatment, and averages are reported in Table 4.

sec.title: Determination of color
sec.p: Spectral reflectance of fish restructured were determined using a portable colorimeter (X-Rite Spectrophotometer model 968, Incorporated, Grandville, MI, USA) calibrated against black and white ties. CIE (Esperanza et al., 2009) L*, a* and b* values were determined. The illuminant used was C and the standard observer position was 2°.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
For comparative purposes, texture parameters and expressible water of turkey breast from 3 trademarks were measured (Table 3). The expressible water varied between 23% and 36%. Warner–Bratzler force varied in the wide range 9.48–15.2 N and Warner–Bratzler work varied in the range 429–786 N·s. These are the targets to obtain a similar texture in resembling fish product. Table 3.
Expressible water and textural parameters measured in commercial products of turkey breast
Range Mean SD
Expressible water (%) 23–36 30.9 6.92
Warner–Bratzler force (N) 9.48–15.2 13.8 3.20
Warner–Bratzler work (N s) 429–786 612 178.7
Tabla 4.
Experimental results achieved for the treatments of the experimental design
Experiment Expressible water (%) Warner–Brazler force (N) Warner–Brazler work (N.s)
1 22.25 35.64 1076
2 28.03 20.01 801
3 31.36 23.93 931
4 44.85 9.44 365
5 27.82 25.55 903
6 46.85 8.18 331
7 26.65 21.31 809
8 33.05 20.24 690
9 26.53 24.15 885
10 41.85 6.17 267
11 22.48 36.34 1263
12 21.45 41.70 1163
13 31.28 11.48 484
14 26.03 13.45 550
15 28.84 24.01 854
16 45.64 10.01 396
17 34.35 5.69 232

The expressible water of restructured Atlantic mackerel products varied between 21.4% and 46.8% (Table 4). The turkey breast showed a mean value of 30.9%. For fish restructured, Warner–Bratzler force varied in the wide range 5.69–41.5 N while the turkey breast showed a mean value of 13.8 N. Warner–Bratzler work was in the range 232–1263 N s in the fish product and the turkey breast showed a value of 612 N s.

All variables studied in the fish products were within the range of the target product, turkey breast. To obtain similar texture parameters as turkey breast, a statistical approach using response surface methodology was used. Listed in Table 4 are the results obtained for each experiment.

Mathematical models were obtained for determining the effect of NaCl concentration, temperature and time of incubation on the above variables. The models help to better understand the process and to find conditions of convenience to obtain a texture and expressible water of the fish product resembling turkey breast. The models obtained are shown in Table 5. The analysis of variances (ANOVA) from the regression equation of each dependent variable allowed the models to be reduced deleting non-significant terms. At the same time, the reduction improves the robustness of the models. Table 5 shows the reduced models and the statistica1 indexes. The value of coefficient of determination r2 is a measure of the amount of variation around the mean, as explained by the model, and does not give useful information about whether this model can be used for all the population and not only for the samples. For this purpose, it is better to compare the values of adjusted r2 and predicted r2. Table 5.
Models obtained and statistical indexes

Parameter adjusted r2 is a measure of the amount of variation around the mean as explained by the model adjusted for the number of terms in the model. The adjusted r2 decreases as the number of terms in the model increases, if those additional terms do not add value to the model. The predicted r2 is defined as a measure of the amount of variation in new data that could be explained by the model. The predicted r2 and the adjusted r2 should be within 0.2 of each other to be in a reasonable agreement. The adequate precision of the model is a measure of the range in predicted response relative to associated error, or, in other words, a signal-to-noise ratio. The desired value is 4 or more (Manson et al., 2003).

All the models obtained showed a predicted r2 in a reasonable agreement with adjusted r2 and an adequate precision in the range 10.6–14.8. Therefore, these statistical indexes found desirable all models.

For the model of expressible water, in concordance with the criterion for the ANOVA test, the term of temperature, interactions between variables and quadratic terms were not significant since theirs p-value were higher than 0.05. The reduction deleting these terms improved the model. The F-value of 26.12 obtained and the value of p-value probability > F less than 0.0001 means that the reduced model shown in Table 5 was significant. The response surface of the model (Rossa et al., 2011) for expressible water with real variables is shown in Figure 1. The F-values for the terms indicate that the most influential term was the NaCl concentration followed by time. The highest level of expressible water (45.64%) was predicted by the model at 30 min and NaCl concentration 0 g/kg and the lowest (21.45%) at 90 min and NaCl concentration 20 g/kg. Figure 1.
Prediction of the model for the dependence of expressive water on time and NaCl concentration at fixed temperature of 32.5 °C.

The model for Warner–Bratzler force (Table 5) includes the significant term after ANOVA. All the linear terms were significant. The model for Warner–Bratzler force showed that the most influential variable was the NaCl concentration, followed by time and temperature. The terms of interaction between variables and quadratic terms were not significant since theirs p-value were higher than 0.05. The F-value of 11.8 and p-value probability > F less than 0.0001 means that the reduced model was significant. Figure 2 shows the response surface for Warner–Bratzler force. Increasing the NaCl concentration and time, at a fixed value of temperature, the value of Warner–Bratzler force increased linearly. The model predicted the highest value (41.5 N) at 20 g/kg of NaCl concentration for 90 min at the central value of temperature. The model predicted the lowest value of Warner–Bratzler force (5.69 N) without addition of NaCl at 32.5 °C for 30 min. Figure 2.
Prediction of the model for the dependence of Warner–Bratzler force on time and NaCl concentration at fixed temperature of 32.5 °C.

The model for Warner–Bratzer work includes the significant term after the ANOVA test. The linear terms were significant. The interaction and quadratic terms were not significant since theirs p-value were higher than 0.05.

The F-value of 11.8 and p-value probability > F less than 0.0001 means that the model for Warner–Bratzler work was significant. The most influential variable in this model was the NaCl concentration, followed by time and temperature. In Figure 3, the value of temperature was fixed at 32.2 °C. The value of Warner–Bratzler work increased with NaCl concentration and time. The model predicted the lowest value (232 N·s) at 0 g/kg of NaCl concentration and 30 min at 32.2 °C. The highest value (1263 N·s) was predicted at 20 g/kg of NaCl concentration for 90 min and at the central level of temperature. Figure 3.
Prediction of the model for the dependence of Warner-Bratzler work on time and NaCl concentration at fixed temperature of 32.5 C.

Applying the models, it is possible to obtain the most similar texture to the turkey breast when considering the number of responses involved in the mechanical properties related with the texture (Martínez et al., 2011).
The constraints considered for the optimization for texture parameters were chosen to obtain similar values of the turkey breast.

The conditions selected by the statistical software that allowed for the fulfillment of the constraints were 31.8 °C, 63.35 min and 8.45 g/kg NaCl concentration. The Warner–Bratzler values predicted for the model using these optimized conditions are shown in Table 6. These values are very close to the values of the turkey breast. Table 6.
Values of the texture and expressible water predicted by the models in the optimal conditions and values found in the experimental confirmation
Predicted values optimized Experimental optimal formulation
Expressible water (%) 33 38.7
Warner–Bratzler force (N) 18.3 7.4
Warner–Bratzler work (N.s) 661 282

A duplicate experiment with the optimized conditions was carried out to confirm the predictions (Table 6). The results showed similar expressible water than turkey breast and a texture slightly softer. Fish is a heterogeneous material and the variations can be due to small differences in the raw material.

For comparative purposes, the values of color for the turkey breast and the experimental optimized fish product were determined (Table 7). No difference was observed for the lightness. However, the color of the fish product was slightly more grayish. Other authors have observed changes in color in restructured fish products (Ramírez et al., 2006; Uresti et al., 2003). However, no significant changes in color between low-salt and regular salt fish gels were observed (Ramírez et al., 2007), indicating that the level of salt did not affect the color in restructured products. Table 7.
Values of color for turkey breast and experimental optimal formulation of restructured
Turkey breast Experimental optimal formulation
L* 74 74.14
a* 3.16 0.17
b* 8.76 12.5

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The results showed the feasibility of producing Atlantic mackerel restructured products resembling turkey breast using transglutaminase to reduce the NaCl concentration without significant loss of textural properties and expressible water. Consequently, a positive effect on heath of the potential consumers is expected.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was financially supported by project AGL2006-08250/ALI (Ministerio de Ciencia e Innovación, Spain).
